did.abstract: Ann Arbor, Michigan, family. Family photographs (portraits and groupings); studio photographs (portraits and groupings) by firms in Ann Arbor, Jackson, and Ypsilanti, Mich.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: This collection was donated by Martha and Einar Kvaran (donor no. 8960) in June 2002.

accruals.p: No further additions to the collection are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has not been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Huhn Family photographs, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Herman A. Huhn, born around 1892, was the son of Ann Arbor constable, Frederick J. Huhn, who died on March 27, 1931. In 1908, he married Ethelyn M. Maddox of Ypsilanti, who died in the late 1920's. After 1928 she disappears from the city directories. They had one son Robert, who was killed in World War II, and two daughters. Herman Huhn retired from the Ann Arbor News as a printer and linotype operator, in 1957 or 1958 and died in 1976 or 1977.

scopecontent.p: This collection is made up of 0.8 linear feet of photographs and 0.1 linear feet of other related material. It contains three series: Family Photographs, Studio Photographs, and Other Material. Both the dated and undated photographs cover the period from 1900 to 1930 but most of them are undated.

The Family Photographs series makes up 0.4 linear feet of the collection. It includes loose photographs, both identified and unidentified, and two photograph albums. The folders are divided into any or all of these categories: photographs of just one person, photographs of two people, photographs of groups of people, either family, friends or both, photographs on postcards, a trip to the zoo and various photographs of the town.

The Studio Photographs series makes up 0.4 linear feet of the collection. It includes Michigan studios in Ann Arbor, Jackson, Ypsilanti, and various other cities, out-of-state studios, and unidentified studios. All of these contain photographs of one person, two people and groups, or various combinations of the three.

The Other Material series makes up 0.1 linear feet of the collection. This series includes various related material that are not photographs. The dates stretch from 1905 until 1950 and materials include dance cards from the Qui Nine Club Dance and the Ann Arbor High Dance, the Elk Club Dedication Book, a wedding invitation to Herman's and Ethelyn's wedding, an insurance card, and a song book with no cover. It also includes negatives of the photographs included in this collection and negatives of different related pictures.
